results.title: Signals : nerves of the army
results.creator_credit: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: During the war, without communication, the soldiers were sitting ducks. Signalmen, like Bruce Christie, may not have been on the front line, but, as Bruce illustrates, their role was just as crucial to the war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Parachute workers
results.creator_credit: Peg Osborne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Despite being discouraged, Peg Osborne wanted to contribute to Australia’s World War II effort. She joined the air force and was sent to Bairnsdale as a textile worker. She reflects on her time there, the work, relations with the male workers, and the sorrows as well as the humour that keep everyone’s spirits up and the friends that Peg will never forget.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peg Osborne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Despite being discouraged, Peg Osborne wanted to contribute to Australia’s World War II effort. She joined the air force and was sent to Bairnsdale as a textile worker. She reflects on her time there, the work, relations with the male workers, and the sorrows as well as the humour that keep everyone’s spirits up and the friends that Peg will never forget.
description_for_label: Despite being discouraged, Peg Osborne wanted to contribute to Australia’s World War II effort. She joined the air force and was sent to Bairnsdale as a textile worker. She reflects on her time there, the work, relations with the male workers, and the sorrows as well as the humour that keep everyone’s spirits up and the friends that Peg will never forget.

results.title: One hour and twelve minutes left to live
results.creator_credit: Charlie Safstrom, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Charlie Safstrom served as a sniper in Borneo during World War II. Here he recounts one of the more frightening moments of his service where he was almost mistaken for a Japanese soldier during a late night changing of the guard.
results.title_for_label: One hour and twelve minutes left to live

results.title: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When he went to the cinemas, the newsreels would beckon David Higgins to ‘Join the Navy and see the world!’. And join the Navy he did, serving in the Mediterranean during World War II. He guides us through the bowels of the ship and the claustrophobic conditions therein. David also reflects on the life-shifting experience of war, how it changed his perspective on things and how little he knew at the time when he signed up.
results.title_for_label: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: When he went to the cinemas, the newsreels would beckon David Higgins to ‘Join the Navy and see the world!’. And join the Navy he did, serving in the Mediterranean during World War II. He guides us through the bowels of the ship and the claustrophobic conditions therein. David also reflects on the life-shifting experience of war, how it changed his perspective on things and how little he knew at the time when he signed up.

results.title: An Interview with Phil Bailey
results.brief_description: Phil Bailey was a telegrapher - one of a unique cohort of women who were trained in signalling by a forward-thinking female engineer. She has never forgotten morse code due to the wise words of her teacher.
results.description: Phil Bailey was a telegrapher - one of a unique cohort of women who were trained in signalling by a forward-thinking female engineer. She has never forgotten morse code due to the wise words of her teacher.

results.title: An Interview with Joyce Bryan
results.brief_description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.
results.description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.

results.title: An Interview with James Ross Irvine
results.brief_description: James Ross Irvine and his brother were both involved in significant battles in Papua New Guinea in World War II. With a stoic sensibility and grim humour, Irvine relates the story of the last time he saw his brother before he was killed in battle.
results.description: James Ross Irvine and his brother were both involved in significant battles in Papua New Guinea in World War II. With a stoic sensibility and grim humour, Irvine relates the story of the last time he saw his brother before he was killed in battle.

results.title: Always a survivor
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI

results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
